author: fox_citizen
content: <@!552133098075193354> Hi, I have read that the merge for PoS has been anticipated to the end of this year around December, is it this right or we are still with the official launch estimate around the Q1 of 2022?

author: sky.cactus
content: There is no official release date or timeline for The Merge.  The soonest is end of this year, but I personally think that is unlikely.

author: sky.cactus
content: Many people think Q1 next year, but I think summer next year still has high probability.  Unforseen roadblocks could delay beyond that though, so take care in any sort of business planning around the switch to Proof of Stake.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are a miner, I recommend financially planning around 2021 Q4 release, if you are someone planning a business around PoS I recommend planning on 2022 Q4.  That way your business will have limited risk regardless of timeline.

author: pietjepuk
content: Does the execution layer client play any part in forming consensus after the merge? What happens if a block is invalid, or if it's invalid according to some clients but not others (e.g. geth says the txs are OK, but others say it's not)

author: potuz
content: Validators need to validate `ExecutionPayload` before syncing the blocks, so a bug in an execution implementation will deem those blocks invalid

author: potuz
content: from the point of view of the validators running that implementation.

author: potuz
content: But notice that they will not attest therefore for those blocks, but later they will include them as canonical

author: potuz
content: if the next block builds upon those and if the execution engine reorgs into the right chain

author: ajsutton
content: If the block execution engine seems the block invalid it will never be included on the canonical chain (fork choice prevents it). Youâ€™d get a chain split same as today.

author: potuz
content: What I meant is that if the execution engine does reorg (therefore accepting it) then the validator also will include it in it's canonical chain

author: potuz
content: Namely the validator will only use lmd + Casper to decide its head

author: potuz
content: And not the previous execution

author: ajsutton
content: Probably just terminology here but a reorg should never change whether a block is valid or invalid. A block may not be able to be validated if the parent block isnâ€™t yet imported which would then be resolved when the parent is available but no reorg is needed there.

author: potuz
content: yes, the situation I had in mind was something like what happened a few weeks ago: a minority of nodes accepting invalid blocks, those nodes may be validating for a block, which others will not validate because they were invalid. Those nodes that validated for the invalid block will include them in their canonical chain as a head, but then later reorg to the majority chain as they did a couple of weeks ago

author: potuz
content: I guess if a vast majority of nodes has a bug and accepts invalid blocks, then we'll see an actual split

author: ajsutton
content: Ah yes. Incorrectly accepting a block tends to get fixed up because the canonical chain doesnâ€™t include them. Incorrectly rejecting a block guarantees a chain split or stall.
